courseTitle: Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering Information Literacy and Research
courseDescription: This course will introduce students to the needs, access, evaluation, use, impact and ethical/legal aspects of information, and to the application of information literacy and research in the fields of mechanical and aerospace engineering.
Technical and Digital Skills: Research application in Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering
Understanding of ethical/legal aspects of information

courseDescription: Principles of materials science with emphasis on the relationship between structure and properties and their control through composition and processing.  Metals, polymers, ceramics, and composite materials are considered.
Technical and Digital Skills: Comprehension of the relationship between structure and properties
Knowledge of metals, polymers, ceramics, and composite materials
Ability to control properties through composition and processing
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in material composition and processing

courseTitle: Mechanical Engineering Laboratory I - Materials Science
courseDescription: This laboratory involves experiments demonstrating lecture material covered in the MAE 201 course.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding and application of lecture material
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying lecture concepts to practical scenarios

courseDescription: Introduction to mechanical engineering problems and their solutions through the study of statics of particles and rigid bodies.  Emphasis will be placed on the relationship of the static loads with the mechanical properties of the materials being considered.  Introduction to the concepts of stress and strain and internal forces as applied to static bodies.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of statics of particles and rigid bodies
Knowledge of mechanical properties of materials
Understanding of the concepts of stress, strain, and internal forces as applied to static bodies
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of statics concepts to solve engineering problems
Ability to relate static loads with mechanical properties

courseDescription: Introduction to engineering problems and their solutions through a study of the dynamics of particles and rigid bodies.  General force systems are studied including friction.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of particle and rigid body dynamics
Understanding and application of friction in engineering problems
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving through the study of dynamics
Analytical skills to understand and solve engineering problems

courseDescription: Introduction to concepts of stress, strain and their relation to each other.  Stress and strain in axially loaded members and circular rods and tubes subjected to torsion.  Normal and shear stress in beams under bending loads.  Additional topics include bending deflection, transformation of stress and strain, Mohr's circles, statically indeterminate problems, combined stress and thin walled pressure vessels.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of axially loaded members and circular rods
Capability to calculate normal and shear stress in beams under bending loads
Application of transformation of stress and strain
Understanding and application of Mohr's circles
Ability to address statically indeterminate problems
Knowledge of thin walled pressure vessels
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical ability to understand complex mechanical concepts
Problem-solving skills in dealing with statically indeterminate problems
Analyzing and interpreting stress and strain curves
Ability to solve complex problems involving various types of stresses

courseTitle: Mechanical Engineering Laboratory II - Solid Mechanics
courseDescription: Experimental study of the mechanical behavior of materials under axial, bending and torsional loads.  Measurements of elastic properties and strengths.  Statistical treatment of data.  Use of strain gauges.  Experiments with composite materials and piezo-electric transducers.  Use of data acquisition system.  Experiments parallel lectures in MAE 220.
Technical and Digital Skills: Experimental study of materials under axial, bending and torsional loads
Measurement of elastic properties and strengths
Working with composite materials and piezo-electric transducers
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing material behavior under various loads
Problem-solving in experimental setup and execution

courseTitle: Engineering Graphics and Computer Solid Modeling
courseDescription: Graphical communication for engineers by means of 3D parametric modeling and its applications in industry. Fundamentals of sketching, basics of surface design, assembly modeling, and dynamic modeling of mechanisms using industry standard parametric modeling software. Emphasis on developing the skills needed for engineering design, including use of engineering standards.
Technical and Digital Skills: Operation of industry standard parametric modeling software

courseDescription: Fundamental concepts, fluid statics, basic equations in integral form, open-channel flow, Bernoulli's equation, dimensional analysis and similitude, incompressible viscous flow, pipe friction, boundary layers, introduction to differential analysis.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of dimensional analysis and similitude
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to explain complex concepts in simple terms
Collaboration in laboratory or field work
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of mathematical principles to solve problems
Critical evaluation of fluid mechanics concepts
Analyzing and understanding complex theoretical concepts

courseDescription: An introduction to thermo-fluid experimentation and measurement; basic flow phenomena demonstrated; measurement techniques for flow temperature, pressure and properties; report writing and data reduction methods, including statistical treatment of data; formal oral reports.
Technical and Digital Skills: Measurement techniques for flow temperature, pressure and properties

courseDescription: Essential definitions of thermodynamics, first law, physical properties, ideal and real gases, second law, reversibility, irreversibility and consequences of thermodynamic cycles.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of the first and second laws of thermodynamics
Ability to differentiate between ideal and real gases
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to articulate understanding of complex thermodynamic principles
Ability to explain differences between ideal and real gases
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to analyze and interpret consequences of thermodynamic cycles
Problem-solving using principles of reversibility and irreversibility

courseDescription: Concepts and principles dealing with thermodynamic cycles, relations and generalized charts, mixtures of fluids, chemical reactions, chemical and phase equilibrium, thermodynamic aspects of fluid flow; introduction to compressible flow, isentropic and normal shock wave relations.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of principles related to mixtures of fluids
Knowledge of chemical reactions and phase equilibrium
Grasping thermodynamic aspects of fluid flow
Comprehension of isentropic and normal shock wave relations
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to explain complex thermodynamic concepts
Collaboration in laboratory or group project settings
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Solving problems related to fluid mixtures
Assessing isentropic and normal shock wave relations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing laboratory tasks in an orderly manner

courseDescription: Fundamental laws of heat transfer by conduction, convection, and radiation; boundary-layer concepts; simultaneous heat, mass, and momentum transfer.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of heat transfer by conduction
Understanding of heat transfer by convection
Understanding of heat transfer by radiation
Understanding of simultaneous heat, mass, and momentum transfer
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to apply fundamental laws of heat transfer to solve problems
Ability to analyze heat and mass transfer scenarios
Analytical skills in evaluating heat, mass, and momentum transfer

courseDescription: Introduction to machine design including review of stress and deflection analysis.  Statistical considerations in design, strength of mechanical elements with emphasis on theories of failure and fatigue design.

Introduction to analog and digital circuits; sensors, actuators and signals; laboratory instrumentation (oscilloscope, function generator, etc.); data acquisition; and embedded microcontroller systems. Students will perform electronics experiments as homework assignments.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of laboratory instrumentation (oscilloscope, function generator, etc.)
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborative learning in a lab environment

courseDescription: A survey of modern computing techniques for mechanical engineers.  Numerical algorithms are presented to solve practical problems in mechanical engineering as found in solid mechanics, fluid mechanics, dynamics, and heat transfer.  Emphasis is on providing computational experience in applied numerical methods using computers. Topics include roots of equations, simultaneous equations, differentiation, integration, regression analysis, interpolation and differential equations.  Analysis, understanding, and quantification of computational errors are included in all topics and applications.
Technical and Digital Skills: Simulation in solid mechanics, fluid mechanics, dynamics, and heat transfer
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis and understanding of computational errors

courseDescription: Available for pass/fail grading only. Student participation for credit based on the academic relevance of the work experience, criteria, and evaluative procedures as formally determined by the department and Career Development Services prior to the semester in which the work experience is to take place.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding and adhering to evaluative procedures
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and planning for work experience
Adhering to professional standards and expectations

courseDescription: Available for pass/fail grading only.  Academic requirements will be established by the department and will vary with the amount of credit desired.  Allows students to gain short duration career-related experience.
Academic requirements will be established by the department and will vary with the amount of credit desired.  Allows students an opportunity to gain short duration career-related experience.

Aircraft concepts including performance prediction and optimization, flight and maneuver envelopes, and steady flight performance.  Additional topics: longitudinal static stability and trim; aircraft dynamics; development, separation and solution of aircraft equations of motion; natural modes; dynamic stability; sensors and actuators; and design of stability augmentation and autopilot systems.
Technical and Digital Skills: Development, separation and solution of aircraft equations of motion
Design of stability augmentation and autopilot systems
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of aircraft stability and dynamic stability
Problem-solving in aircraft equation of motion

courseDescription: Free and forced vibrations of undamped and damped, single-degree of freedom, multi-degree of freedom, and continuous systems.  Exact and approximate methods to find natural frequencies.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of free and forced vibrations
Knowledge of undamped and damped vibrations
Ability to work with single-degree of freedom systems
Ability to work with multi-degree of freedom systems
Exact and approximate methods to find natural frequencies
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical skills for exact and approximate methods
Ability to handle complex multi-degree of freedom systems

courseDescription: Inviscid flow concepts including: Euler equations, stream function, velocity potential, singularities, vorticity and circulation laws.  Viscous flow topics including boundary layers, separation, and turbulent flow. In addition, external flows, lift and drag, thin airfoil theory, finite wing theory and airfoil design will be discussed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of vorticity and circulation laws
Application of separation in viscous flow
Understanding and application of turbulent flow
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying theoretical knowledge to practical scenarios

courseTitle: Mechanical Engineering Power Systems Theory and Design
courseDescription: Thermodynamic properties of gases and vapors relating to power generating devices, work-energy relations, combustion, and heat exchangers.  Performance analyses and design concepts of gas turbines, internal combustion engines, steam power plants and heat exchanger equipment from theoretical and applied viewpoints.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of thermodynamic properties of gases and vapors
Performance analysis and design of gas turbines
Performance analysis and design of internal combustion engines
Performance analysis and design of steam power plants
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presentation of design concepts and performance analyses
Collaboration in design and implementation processes
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in design and analysis of heat exchangers
Problem-solving in design and analysis of gas turbines
Problem-solving in design and analysis of internal combustion engines
Problem-solving in design and analysis of steam power plants
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management in design and performance analysis

courseDescription: Engineering principles as applied to the analysis and design of systems for automatically controlling man or machine environments.  Course encompasses fundamentals of heating, ventilating, air conditioning, refrigeration, cryogenics, and design of building energy systems.
Technical and Digital Skills: Heating, ventilating, air conditioning (HVAC) system design
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving for HVAC, refrigeration, cryogenics, and building energy systems

courseDescription: Introduction of relevant kinetic theory, solid state, and thermodynamic principles; operation and analysis of thermoelectric, photovoltaic, thermionic, magnetohydrodynamic devices, fuel cell, isotopic, and solar power generators.  Course seeks to define engineering limits of converter efficiency and other performance criteria.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding and operation of magnetohydrodynamic devices
Understanding and operation of solar power generators

courseDescription: One-dimensional compressible flow considering isentropic flow, normal shocks, flow in constant area ducts with friction, flow in ducts with heating and cooling, oblique shocks, Prandtl-Meyer expansions, shock-expansion theory, flow around diamond shaped airfoils, and wind tunnel mechanics.
Technical and Digital Skills: Flow analysis in constant area ducts with friction
Flow analysis in ducts with heating and cooling
Flow analysis around diamond shaped airfoils
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to analyze and interpret complex fluid dynamics
Problem-solving in various gas dynamics scenarios
Analytical skills to evaluate flow in different conditions
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Ability to apply theoretical knowledge in practical scenarios
Managing and organizing data and results from experiments

courseDescription: Basic principles of design, operation and performance of propulsion systems - including turbojet, turboprop, turbofan, and ramjet engines.  Introduction to chemical rockets, ion and plasma thrusters.
Technical and Digital Skills: Operation of turbojet, turboprop, turbofan, and ramjet engines
Knowledge on ion and plasma thrusters

courseDescription: Analysis of aircraft and space vehicle structural components.  Effects of bending, torsion and shear on typical aerospace structural components, statically indeterminate beams, shear center and shear flow.  Introduction to typical aerospace structures.  Introduction to composite structures.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analysis of aircraft and space vehicle structural components
Understanding effects of bending, torsion and shear on typical aerospace structural components
Knowledge of statically indeterminate beams, shear center and shear flow
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem solving in bending, torsion and shear effects

courseDescription: Limitations of conventional materials; inter-relationship among materials, design and processing, material selection criteria and procedures; strengthening mechanisms in metals; superelasticity; shape memory effect, amorphous metals; structure-property relationship in polymers; polymers crystallinity; thermoplastic and thermosets; high-temperature restraint polymers; ceramics; toughening mechanisms in ceramics.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of limitations of conventional materials
Knowledge of inter-relationship among materials, design and processing
Understanding of strengthening mechanisms in metals
Knowledge of toughening mechanisms in ceramics
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Material selection based on design and processing requirements

courseDescription: Basic relations necessary for analysis of plane motion mechanisms, numerical and analytical solutions for some of the basic mechanisms, methods of calculating rolling and sliding velocities and accelerations of contacting bodies, cams, and gears.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical thinking in relation to plane motion mechanisms

courseDescription: Statistical considerations in design, strength of mechanical elements with emphasis on theories of failure and fatigue design in mechanical elements such as screws, fasteners, connections, welded joints, and flexible mechanical elements. Kinematic analysis, force analysis, and design of spur, helical, worm, and bevel gears.  Antifriction bearings, lubrication and journal bearings, shaft design, mechanical spring design, design of clutches, brakes and couplings.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding and applying theories of failure and fatigue design
Designing mechanical elements such as screws, fasteners, connections, welded joints, and flexible mechanical elements
Design of spur, helical, worm, and bevel gears
Working with antifriction bearings, lubrication and journal bearings
Design of clutches, brakes and couplings
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing and improving lubrication and bearing systems

courseDescription: This course prepares students to complete their design projects in MAE 435.  Lecture topics include engineering economics; project planning; costing and risk analysis; and product realization techniques.  Course involves written and oral presentations for students to improve communication and teamwork skills. This is a writing intensive course.

Conceptual design ideas are expanded into detailed design ideas. Product realization is applied to complete hardware.  Course covers Gantt charts, preliminary design, evaluation and trading matrices, detailed design and analysis, oral and technical reporting including cost analysis.  Ethics and patent issues are also included.

Analysis and synthesis of feedback systems; functional description of dynamic systems; basic controllers; sensitivity, stability and error analysis; transient and steady-state response using computational techniques, root locus and frequency response methods; state-space analysis of control systems.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analysis and synthesis of feedback systems
Transient and steady-state response using computational techniques
Application of root locus and frequency response methods

courseDescription: Computer-aided analysis and design of practical control systems.  Introduction to state-space, digital signal processing and digital control.  Laboratory sessions on aliasing, analog, system identification, and real-time control.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification and resolution of system aliasing

courseDescription: Basic concepts of finite-element method, method of weighted residuals, interpolation functions, numerical implementation of finite-element method, applications to engineering problems such as beam deflection, heat conduction, and plane elastic problems.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of basic concepts of finite-element method
Knowledge of method of weighted residuals
Ability to implement numerical methods of finite-element method
Application of finite-element method to engineering problems

courseDescription: Case studies are used to introduce students to CAD software; design processes involving modeling, analysis and design, and verification.  Typical case studies are beam and plate designs, turbine blade design, and pipe networks.  Advanced topics include:  thermal stress analysis and plates and shells.
Technical and Digital Skills: Designing plates, shells, and turbine blades
Analysis and verification of mechanical designs
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying theoretical knowledge to practical design scenarios

courseDescription: Introduction to spacecraft systems starting from mission design and space environment considerations and proceeding through propulsion, altitude control, spacecraft structural design, thermal control, power and communications for spacecraft.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of power and communications for spacecraft

courseTitle: Topics in Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering
courseDescription: Special topics of interest with emphasis placed on recent developments in mechanical and aerospace engineering or engineering mechanics. (offered fall, spring, summer)
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of recent developments in mechanical and aerospace engineering
Ability to apply engineering mechanics in practical contexts
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to engage in discussions on special topics of interest in the engineering field
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing new developments in mechanical and aerospace engineering

courseTitle: Topics in Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering
courseDescription: Special topics of interest with emphasis placed on recent developments in mechanical engineering or engineering mechanics. (offered fall, spring, summer)
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of recent developments in mechanical engineering
Ability to comprehend and apply advanced mechanical concepts
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to explain complex mechanical concepts
Sharing ideas and findings on recent developments in the field
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing and interpreting new mechanical and aerospace engineering concepts
Problem-solving in relation to mechanical engineering challenges
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Keeping up-to-date with advancements in the field
Ability to lead discussions on recent developments in mechanical engineering

courseTitle: Independent Study in Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering
courseDescription: Individual analytical, computational, and/or experimental study in an area selected by student.  Supervised and approved by the advisor.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analytical skills in mechanical and aerospace engineering

courseDescription: Aircraft concepts including performance prediction and optimization, flight and maneuver envelopes, and steady flight performance.  Additional topics: longitudinal static stability and trim; aircraft dynamics; development, separation and solution of aircraft equations of motion; natural modes; dynamic stability; sensors and actuators; and design of stability augmentation and autopilot systems.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of flight and maneuver envelopes
Longitudinal static stability and trim analysis
Development, separation and solution of aircraft equations of motion
Design of stability augmentation and autopilot systems

Analysis and optimization of flight performance
Design and troubleshooting of stability augmentation and autopilot systems

courseDescription: Free and forced vibrations of undamped and damped, single-degree of freedom, multi-degree of freedom, and continuous systems.  Exact and approximate methods to find natural frequencies.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analysis of free and forced vibrations
Understanding of undamped and damped systems
Knowledge of single-degree and multi-degree of freedom systems
Application of exact and approximate methods to find natural frequencies
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of approximate methods in problem-solving

courseDescription: Inviscid flow concepts including: Euler equations, stream function, velocity potential, singularities, vorticity and circulation laws.  Viscous flow topics including boundary layers separation, and turbulent flow. In addition, external flows, lift and drag, thin airfoil theory, finite wing theory and airfoil design will be discussed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Comprehension of stream function and velocity potential
Knowledge of vorticity and circulation laws
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to solve complex aerodynamic problems

courseDescription: Thermodynamic properties of gases and vapors relating to power generating devices, work-energy relations, combustion, and heat exchangers. courseDescription: Engineering principles as applied to the analysis and design of systems for automatically controlling man or machine environments.  Course encompasses fundamentals of heating, ventilating, air conditioning, refrigeration, cryogenics, and design of building energy systems.

Introduction of relevant kinetic theory, solid state, and thermodynamic principles; operation and analysis of thermoelectric, photovoltaic, thermionic, magnetohydrodynamic devices, fuel cell, isotopic, and solar power generators.  Course seeks to define engineering limits of converter efficiency and other performance criteria.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding and operation of thermionic devices
Understanding and operation of solar power generators

courseDescription: One-dimensional compressible flow considering isentropic flow, normal shocks, flow in constant area ducts with friction, flow in ducts with heating and cooling, oblique shocks, Prandtl-Meyer expansions, shock-expansion theory, flow around diamond shaped airfoils, and wind tunnel mechanics.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of flow in constant area ducts with friction
Understanding of flow in ducts with heating and cooling

Ability to solve problems related to compressible flow

courseDescription: Basic principles of design, operation and performance of propulsion systems - including turbojet, turboprop, turbofan, and ramjet engines.  Introduction to chemical rockets, ion and plasma thrusters.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of turbojet, turboprop, turbofan, and ramjet engines
Understanding of ion and plasma thrusters

courseDescription: Analysis of aircraft and space vehicle structural components.  Effects of bending, torsion and shear on typical aerospace structural components, statically indeterminate beams, shear center and shear flow.  Introduction to typical aerospace structures.  Introduction to composite structures.

Understanding the effects of bending, torsion and shear on aerospace structures

courseDescription: Computer-aided analysis and design of practical control systems.  Introduction to state-space, digital signal processing and digital control.  Laboratory sessions on aliasing, analog, system identification, and real-time control.

courseDescription: Basic concepts of finite-element method, method of weighted residuals, interpolation functions, numerical implementation of finite-element method, applications to engineering problems such as beam deflection, heat conduction, and plane elastic problems.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of method of weighted residuals
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying finite element analysis to solve beam deflection issues

courseDescription: Basic principles of naval architecture related to ship geometry, stability, strength, resistance, propulsion, vibration and motions in waves and controllability.

Introduction to spacecraft systems starting from mission design and space environment considerations and proceeding through propulsion, altitude control, spacecraft structural design, thermal control, power and communications for spacecraft.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing and solving issues in altitude control
Analyzing and solving issues in power and communication systems

courseTitle: Topics in Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering
courseDescription: Special topics of interest with emphasis placed on recent developments in mechanical and aerospace engineering or engineering mechanics. (offered fall, spring, summer)
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of mechanical and aerospace engineering principles
Knowledge of recent developments in mechanical and aerospace engineering
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in mechanical and aerospace engineering

courseTitle: Independent Study in Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering
courseDescription: Individual analytical, computational, and/or experimental study in an area selected by student.  Supervised and approved by the advisor.
Applications of linear algebra, ordinary and partial differential equations, and complex variables to engineering problems.
Technical and Digital Skills: Solving ordinary and partial differential equations

courseDescription: Conservation laws for viscous and inviscid flows.  Boundary conditions; analytical and numerical solution of viscous flow problems; boundary-layer theory; 2 and 3-dimensional potential flows; applications to airfoils, wings, and internal flows; introduction to turbulence.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding and application of conservation laws for viscous and inviscid flows
Analytical and numerical solution of viscous flow problems
Application of theories to airfoils, wings, and internal flows
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing and solving viscous flow problems
Application of analytical and numerical methods to solve fluid dynamics problems
Problem-solving in application to airfoils, wings, and internal flows

courseDescription: Stress, strain, equilibrium for deformable solids; material behavior of elasticity, hyperelasticity, plasticity and viscoelasticity; failure criteria, fracture; thermal effect; energy methods and their applications to bars and beams for static, stability and dynamic problems.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of stress, strain, equilibrium for deformable solids
Knowledge of material behavior of elasticity, hyperelasticity, plasticity and viscoelasticity
Proficiency in energy methods and their applications to bars and beams for static, stability and dynamic problems
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in static, stability and dynamic problems

courseDescription: Advanced kinematics with moving reference frames.  Euler equations of motion.  Gyroscopic theory.  Principle of virtual work, D'Alembert's principle, Hamilton's principle, Lagrange's equations of motion and rigid body dynamics.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of Euler equations of motion
Application of Lagrange's equations of motion
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying theoretical principles to practical dynamics problems

courseDescription: Rigorous development of the macroscopic theory of thermodynamics; structural basis for equations of state and general properties of matter; phase and chemical equilibria.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of macroscopic theory of thermodynamics
Ability to derive equations of state
Understanding of phase and chemical equilibria

courseDescription: Indicial notations and tensor calculus; strain and stress tensors, rate of deformation tensor, Eulerian and Lagrangian descriptions, conservation principles, constitutive formulations for elastic solids and viscous fluids, formulation of fluid mechanics and solid mechanics problems.  Simple applications.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of indicial notations and tensor calculus
Knowledge of strain and stress tensors
Understanding of rate of deformation tensor
Familiarity with Eulerian and Lagrangian descriptions
Ability to formulate constitutive formulations for elastic solids and viscous fluids
Proficiency in formulating fluid mechanics and solid mechanics problems
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to apply principles of continuum mechanics to simple applications
Analytical skills to understand complex mechanical problems

courseDescription: Linear algebra.  Vectors and matrices.  Partial differential equations.  Curve fittings.  Applied probabilities.  Statistics of distributions.  Testing of hypotheses and decisions.  Quality control.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding and solving partial differential equations

courseDescription: Aspects of conduction, convection and radiation heat transfer, including governing equations, boundary layer flows, analytical and numerical solutions to one-, two-, and three-dimensional problems.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of conduction, convection and radiation heat transfer
Proficiency in analytical and numerical solutions
Ability to solve one-, two-, and three-dimensional problems
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Capability to apply numerical solutions in practical scenarios
Critical evaluation of heat transfer problems

courseDescription: Formulation of state space equations governing dynamics and stability of linear systems.  Controllability; observability.  State feedback control design.  Optimal control methods.  State observers and estimators.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of linear systems dynamics and stability

courseTitle: Cooperative Education in Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering
courseDescription: Student participation for credit based on academic relevance of the work experience, criteria, and evaluative procedures as formally determined by the department and the Cooperative Education program prior to the semester in which the work experience is to take place.
Technical and Digital Skills: Practical application of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering principles
Use of technical tools relevant to the field
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication within a professional environment
Collaborative work with department and Cooperative Education program
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying academic knowledge to practical scenarios
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing work experience for academic credit
Following and understanding the formal criteria set by the department and Cooperative Education program

courseTitle: Internship in Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering
courseDescription: Academic requirements will be established by the department and will vary with the amount of credit desired.  Allows students an opportunity to gain short duration career-related experience.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical thinking in mechanical and aerospace contexts
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management in an engineering context
Time management for complex engineering tasks

courseTitle: Practicum in Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering
courseDescription: Academic requirements will be established by the department and will vary with the amount of credit desired.  Allows students an opportunity to gain short duration career-related experience. Student is usually already employed--this is an additional project within the organization.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Professional communication with supervisors and colleagues

courseDescription: This course will focus on formal experiment design. Topics to be discussed will include review of statistics, ANOVA, multiple comparisons, residuals, modal adequacy checking, randomized complete block designs, factorial designs, 2^k factorial and fractional factorial designs, random and mixed effects in factorials, and optimization. The course will also provide an introduction to response surface methods.  Laboratory exercises will use designed experiments as applied to aerospace testing, including wind tunnel testing and instrument calibration.
Technical and Digital Skills: Random and mixed effects in factorials

courseDescription: Study of principles of concurrent engineering with emphasis on the design/manufacture interface for single products; Rapid prototyping projects; Designof injection-molded and stamped parts for cost.
Technical and Digital Skills: Study of principles of concurrent engineering

courseDescription: Project(s) course to allow graduate students to complete a practical engineering assignment in design and manufacturing areas.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Team leadership in design and manufacturing projects

courseDescription: Regular tutorials on recent topics of interest in mechanical and aerospace engineering and engineering mechanics.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of mechanical and aerospace engineering concepts
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion of recent topics in engineering
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of recent developments in mechanical and aerospace engineering

courseTitle: Topics in Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering
courseDescription: Special topics of interest with emphasis placed on recent developments in mechanical and aerospace engineeringor engineering mechanics.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of recent developments in mechanical and aerospace engineering
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to analyze and interpret complex engineering problems

courseDescription: An independent laboratory experience in the area of either aerodynamics, structural dynamics or applied automatic control.  Results will be reported in a format and quality similar to a technical conference paper.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in aerodynamics, structural dynamics or applied automatic control

courseTitle: Independent Study in Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering
courseDescription: Individual analytical, computational and/or experimental study in an area selected by the student.  Supervised and approved by the advisor.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge in selected mechanical and aerospace engineering area
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presentation of experimental findings and computational results

courseTitle: Master’s Project in Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering
courseDescription: Individual project, investigation under the direction of the student's major professor.
Technical and Digital Skills: Design and testing of mechanical and aerospace systems
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of engineering principles to real-world problems

courseTitle: Thesis Research in Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering
courseDescription: Thesis research in mechanical and aerospace engineering or engineering mechanics leading to the Master of Science degree.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of engineering principles to solve problems

courseDescription: This course will examine governing equations for supersonic flow, including full potential equations, small disturbance theory, hodographs, and method of characteristics. It will also serve as an introduction to three-dimensional flows, compressible boundary layer flows, internal flows in nozzles and diffusers, airfoil flows, slender bodies of revolution flows, conical flows, and wing flows.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of governing equations for supersonic flow
Knowledge of hodographs and method of characteristics
Knowledge of compressible boundary layer flows
Understanding of internal flows in nozzles and diffusers
Understanding of slender bodies of revolution flows
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to analyze complex supersonic flow problems
Skills to apply different theories in solving supersonic flow problems
Analytical skills to understand and interpret different types of flows
Problem-solving skills to identify and understand issues in supersonic flow

courseDescription: General consideration of hypersonic flow and similarity principles, hypersonic flow past slender bodies with sharp and blunt leading edges.  Hypersonic blunt-body flow. Real gas, viscous and low density effects, and consideration of nonequilibrium phenomena in hypersonic flows.
Technical and Digital Skills: Ability to analyze hypersonic flow past slender bodies
Understanding of real gas, viscous and low density effects
Consideration of nonequilibrium phenomena in hypersonic flows
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of real gas, viscous and low density effects in problem solving
Understanding nonequilibrium phenomena in problem-solving contexts

courseDescription: This course will examine techniques for static and dynamic measurement of pressure, temperature, and velocity. Experiment control and statistical treatment of data will be discussed, as will probe methods, including multi-hole pressure probes and hot-wire anemometers, and non-intrusive methods, including laser Doppler velocimetry and other optical methods. Surface and stream flow visualization and surface measurements will also be covered.
Technical and Digital Skills: Non-intrusive methods such as laser Doppler velocimetry
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding and interpretation of experimental results
Techniques for visualizing and interpreting surface and stream flow

courseDescription: Isotropic and homogeneous turbulence.  Mixing length theories, Equilibrium turbulence models, Two-equation models (k-epsilon).  Large eddy simulation.  Reynold's stress transport models.  Numerical simulations.  Compressible and non-equilibrium turbulence effects.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of isotropic and homogeneous turbulence
Knowledge of compressible and non-equilibrium turbulence effects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Simulating large eddy and equilibrium turbulence

courseDescription: Boundary layer equations; method of matched asymptotic expansions; body oriented coordinates, finite-difference solutions; separations, wake and jet flows; thermal and compressible boundary layers, transformations and finite-difference solutions, unsteady boundary layers.  Introduction to hydrodynamic stability and turbulence.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of method of matched asymptotic expansions
Capability to handle separations, wake and jet flows
Understanding of thermal and compressible boundary layers
Ability to apply transformations and finite-difference solutions
Introduction to hydrodynamic stability and turbulence
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical understanding of complex fluid dynamics problems
Ability to identify and solve for separations, wake and jet flows
Problem-solving in thermal and compressible boundary layers

courseDescription: This course will cover the following topics: classification of single partial differential equations; finite difference methods; stability analysis, including convergence, consistency, and efficiency; basics of finite volume methods; model equations of hyperbolic, parabolic and elliptic type; and explicit and implicit schemes, central and upwind schemes, and weak solutions of quasi-linear hyperbolic equations.
Technical and Digital Skills: Classification of Single Partial Differential Equations
Understanding of Model Equations of Hyperbolic, Parabolic and Elliptic Type
Understanding of Weak Solutions of Quasi-Linear Hyperbolic Equations
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem Solving with Finite Difference Methods
Understanding and Analyzing Various Types of Model Equations
Analyzing and Implementing Explicit and Implicit Schemes

courseDescription: A comprehensive examination of aerodynamic test facilities for use in subsonic, transonic, supersonic and hypersonic flow regimes. Aspects of wind tunnel design and operation will be discussed, as will flow quality and wall and support interferences. Advanced concepts including cryogenic wind tunnels, adaptive wall test sections and magnetic suspension will be examined, in addition to dynamic testing. There will be a review of flight test methods, including extraction of aerodynamic parameters from flight test data, a review of engine test facilities, and a review of ground test facilities for space structures and other space systems.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of subsonic, transonic, supersonic and hypersonic flow regimes
Understanding of flow quality and wall and support interferences
Knowledge of cryogenic wind tunnels, adaptive wall test sections and magnetic suspension
Extraction of aerodynamic parameters from flight test data
Review of ground test facilities for space structures and other space systems
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluation and interpretation of flight test data

courseDescription: Aspects of conduction, convection and radiation heat transfer, including governing equations, boundary layer flows, analytical and numerical solutions to one-, two- and three-dimensional problems.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of conduction, convection, and radiation heat transfer
Ability to apply governing equations in heat transfer
Analytical and numerical solutions to one-, two- and three-dimensional problems
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to solve complex heat transfer problems
Analytical thinking in heat transfer scenarios

courseDescription: This course will consider nuclear power plant systems, and will introduce power reactor control kinetic behavior including safety coefficients, accumulative poisons, and temperature control parameters. It will also examine primary and secondary plant as a transient system.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of nuclear power plant systems
Knowledge of power reactor control kinetic behavior
Ability to examine primary and secondary plant as a transient system
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to analyze the behavior of nuclear power plant systems
Capability to troubleshoot issues related to safety coefficients and accumulative poisons
Ability to analyze temperature control parameters

courseDescription: This course provides an understanding of the finite element method (FEM) as derived from an integral formulation perspective. It demonstrates the solutions of (1-D and 2-D) continuum mechanics problems such as solid mechanics, fluid mechanics and heat transfer. It also provides insight into the theoretical formulation and numerical implementation of finite element methods.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of the finite element method (FEM)
Solution derivation for continuum mechanics problems
Theoretical formulation of finite element methods
Numerical implementation of finite element methods
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of finite element method in solving mechanics problems

courseDescription: Stress-strain relations for a lamina; failure theories.  Micro-mechanical behavior of a lamina.  Constitutive relations of a laminate.  Bending, buckling and vibration of laminated plates.  Approximate and finite element methods of solution.
Technical and Digital Skills: Bending, buckling and vibration analysis of laminated plates
Understanding and applying approximate and finite element methods of solution
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing and solving problems related to stress-strain relations
Application of failure theories to solve practical problems
Analyzing micro-mechanical behavior of a lamina
Applying constitutive relations of a laminate to solve real-world problems
Problem solving in bending, buckling and vibration of laminated plates
Use of approximate and finite element methods of solution for problem solving

courseDescription: This course will introduce applied modal analysis, modes of vibration of discrete systems, modal coordinates, transfer functions in frequency domain, modes of vibration of continuous systems, and approximate systems response. It will also examine Finite Elements methods and nonlinear vibrations. Applications will be extended to rods, beams, plates and shells.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of vibration modes in discrete systems
Usage of transfer functions in frequency domain
Understanding of vibration modes in continuous systems
Understanding and application of vibration theories to rods, beams, plates and shells
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing and interpreting the modes of vibration
Applying modal analysis to solve vibration problems
Using Finite Elements methods to solve complex problems
Analytical skills to understand and interpret nonlinear vibrations

courseTitle: Autonomous and Robotic Systems Analysis and Control
courseDescription: Kinematics, dynamics and control of complex non-linear electro-mechanical systems, particularly robotic manipulators.

Parameter optimization, optimization problem for dynamic systems with terminal and path constraints; optimal feedback control with and without the presence of uncertainty; nonlinear optimal control system.
Technical and Digital Skills: Optimization problem solving for dynamic systems with terminal and path constraints
Applying optimal feedback control with and without the presence of uncertainty
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing and solving complex optimization problems
Understanding and applying path constraints in dynamic systems

courseDescription: Basic theories are presented for formulation of equations of kinematics and dynamics of systems made of interconnected bodies.  Topics include constrained motion, principle of virtual work and constrained dynamics.  Examples cover robotic motion and biomechanics applications such as human locomotion.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of principle of virtual work
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Systematic analysis of interconnected body systems
Application of theoretical principles to practical examples
Analyzing and interpreting kinematic and dynamic equations

courseDescription: Classification of mechanisms; type and number synthesis, application of graph theory, expert systems for synthesis; introduction to dimensional synthesis via path and function generation; finite displacement theory including concept of poles, circlepoint, and centerpoint curves; structural error minimization using Chebychev's approximation; optimization approaches, current applications to robot manipulators, robot hands, space structures, and combustion engines.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of poles, circlepoint, and centerpoint curves
Structural error minimization using Chebychev's approximation
Knowledge on robot manipulators, robot hands, space structures, and combustion engines
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem solving with finite displacement theory
Application of dimensional synthesis for path and function generation

courseDescription: Principles governing the dynamics and control of vehicles in atmospheric flight.  Equations of motion development and solution including inertial/gravitational/aerodynamic/propulvsive loads, linear longitudinal and lateral-directional motions, and nonlinear trim and simulation.  Flight control system design and analysis incorporating flying quality requirements, linear conventional/contemporary and frequency/time domain techniques for control and guidance functions, validation with nonlinear simulation, gain scheduling.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of principles governing the dynamics and control of vehicles in atmospheric flight
Equations of motion development and solution
Understanding of linear longitudinal and lateral-directional motions
Understanding and application of nonlinear trim and simulation
Flight control system design and analysis
Knowledge of linear conventional/contemporary and frequency/time domain techniques for control and guidance functions
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of frequency/time domain techniques for control and guidance functions

courseDescription: Principles governing the dynamics and control of vehicles in space flight.  Equations of motion development and solution including inertial/gravitational/aerodynamic/propulsive loads, decoupled translational and attitude motions.  Ortibal mechanics including elements, initial-value propagation, adjustments/transfers, Lambert boundary-value problem, perturbations, and nonlinear simulation.  Attitude dynamics including torque free, gravity moment, axisymmetric/unsymmetric vehicles, and dual spinners.  Flight control system design and analysis including impulsive velocities, finite burns, Lambert targeting, linear designusing momentum wheels, and nonlinear phase-plane design using thrusters.
Technical and Digital Skills: Flight control system design and analysis
Equations of motion development and solution

courseDescription: Review of multivariable dynamic math models including state space, transfer function, and matrix fractions.  Multivariable design criteria including stability, performance,and robustness.  Theory and application of multivariable control design techniques including LQR/LQG/LTR, H-infinity, Eigenspace Assignment and other advanced methods.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of advanced control design techniques
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of multivariable design criteria including stability, performance, and robustness
Application of theory to multivariable control design

courseDescription: This course will study the flight performance of aerospace vehicles, including a review of aerodynamic and propulsion characteristics. Range, flight and maneuver envelopes for vehicles in atmospheric flight will also be examined. It will introduce various methods of design for trajectory optimization, including launch vehicles. An open-ended, design-oriented project will be required.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of aerodynamic and propulsion characteristics

courseDescription: This course will provide an overview of the governing principles and operations of actuator and sensor hardware used in aircraft and spacecraft flight control systems. Hydraulic, electro-hydraulic and electric actuators will be examined, as well as control jets and momentum wheels, accelerometers, and rate gyros. Other topics include air-data systems, inertial navigation systems and satellite navigation systems. The course will also examine dynamic model development, analysis and simulation, nonlinear hardware characteristics, and the influence on closed-loop vehicle behavior.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of actuator and sensor hardware
Knowledge of hydraulic, electro-hydraulic and electric actuators
Understanding of control jets and momentum wheels
Familiarity with accelerometers and rate gyros
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the influence on closed-loop vehicle behavior
Analysis and simulation of dynamic models
Understanding and managing nonlinear hardware characteristics

courseTitle: Nanoscale Mechanical and Structural Properties of Materials
courseDescription: Elastic and plastic properties of nanoscale materials, strain gradient dislocation plasticity, nanoindentation and nanoindentation creep, thin film mechanical and structural properties, kinetic-based investigations of hardening mechanisms in nanolayer composites.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of elastic and plastic properties of nanoscale materials
Knowledge of strain gradient dislocation plasticity
Competence in nanoindentation and nanoindentation creep
Understanding of thin film mechanical and structural properties
Experience with kinetic-based investigations of hardening mechanisms in nanolayer composites
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Investigating hardening mechanisms in nanolayer composites

courseDescription: Divided into areas of fatigue and fracture; stress-controlled and strain-controlled fatigue; effect of mean stresses, notches, etc.; multiaxial stresses; variable amplitude loading; ductile and brittle fracture; linear elastic fracture mechanics; crack-tip plasticity; fracture testing; applications to fatigue life estimation.  Requires permission of the instructor.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of fatigue and fracture mechanics
Knowledge of stress-controlled and strain-controlled fatigue
Identification of the effects of mean stresses and notches
Differentiation between ductile and brittle fractures
Application of linear elastic fracture mechanics
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluating the impact of variable amplitude loading

courseDescription: This course will examine the macroscopic behavior of materials with respect to elasticity, plasticity, and viscoelasticity. Other topics include yield criteria, fracture, the influence of high and low temperatures, and corrosion and radiation.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of elasticity, plasticity, and viscoelasticity
Comprehension of the influence of high and low temperatures on materials
Knowledge of corrosion and radiation effects on materials
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to explain complex material behavior concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the effects of various conditions on material behavior
Problem-solving in relation to material failures

courseDescription: This course will examine reinforcements, matrices, particulate-composites, short-fiber and continuous-fiber reinforced composites. Directionally solidified composites will also be studied, including the prediction of elastic failure properties. Other topics to be covered include design considerations and experimental work.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of short-fiber and continuous-fiber reinforced composites

courseDescription: An applied course in response surface methodology with aerospace applications.  Empirical model building, method of least squares, second order models, model adequacy checking, canonical analysis.  Method of steepest ascent, multiple response optimization.  Rotatable, cuboidal and small run designs.  Design optimality and efficiency metrics, robust design, restrictions on randomization.  Laboratory exercises include RSM applied to wind tunnel testing and optimization.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and conducting wind tunnel tests
Implementing design optimality and efficiency metrics

courseDescription: Formulation and solution algorithms for Linear Programming (LP) problems.  Unconstrained and constrained nonlinear programming (NLP) problems.  Optimum solution for practical engineering systems.
Technical and Digital Skills: Optimum solution for practical engineering systems

courseDescription: Concepts, principles and procedures related to analysis of stresses and strains in machine components.  Consideration of function of parts along with factors such as forces, life required, maximum cost, weight and space restrictions, number of parts to be produced, material selection, kinematics,environmental restrictions.  Finite element analysis to illustrate different aspects of stress analysis.  Requires permission of the instructor.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Considering factors such as forces, cost, weight, space restrictions
Analyzing number of parts to be produced
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management considering different constraints and requirements

courseDescription: This course will introduce the engineering of industrial robots used for manufacturing automation. Topics to be covered include spatial descriptions and transformations of manipulators, manipulator kinematics and inverse kinematics; manipulator velocities; static forces; and dynamics and trajectory generation. Other topics to be covered include design and on-line computer control of the manipulator.
Technical and Digital Skills: Spatial descriptions and transformations of manipulators
Design and on-line computer control of manipulator
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding and applying spatial descriptions and transformations
Applying kinematics and inverse kinematics principles
Understanding and applying dynamics and trajectory generation
Designing and controlling manipulator through computer

courseDescription: Treatment of the next generation of manufacturing technology.  Topics include additive manufacturing; rapid prototypying; electronic manufacturing; micro and nanofabrication; process simulation; product life cycle management; and sustainable design and manufacturing.

courseTitle: Computational Intelligence for Engineering Design Optimization Problems
courseDescription: The concepts and algorithms of computational intelligence and their application to engineering design are discussed, including artificial neural networks, evolutionary optimization, and swarm intelligence. Both single and multi-objective optimization problems with continuous and/or discrete variables are also discussed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Solution of single objective optimization problems
Handling of continuous and discrete variables
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing and solving complex engineering design problems
Applying computational intelligence algorithms for problem solving
Managing multiple objectives in optimization problems

courseDescription: An introduction to managing uncertainties and risk in strength design of mechanical components, including the study of the theoretical background, computational implementation, and applications of reliability-based methods for engineering analysis and design.
Technical and Digital Skills: Managing uncertainties and risk in strength design

courseDescription: A broad introduction to the field of cellular biomechanics. Topics include overview of cell architecture, cytoskeleton, adhesion and molecular motors, biomolecular/biopolymer dynamics and mechanics, techniques to measure cell mechanical properties, techniques to mechanically stimulate cells, models of cell mechanical behavior, mechanobiology and mechanotransduction. Will include discussion of classic and current research articles.   Course content will aim to cater to students with diverse backgrounds – students with biological science background will be exposed to physical science concepts and analysis; students with engineering/physical science background will be exposed to biological phenomena and concepts.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of cytoskeleton, adhesion and molecular motors
Understanding of biomolecular/biopolymer dynamics and mechanics
Application of techniques to measure cell mechanical properties
Usage of techniques to mechanically stimulate cells
Ability to model cell mechanical behavior
Understanding and application of mechanobiology and mechanotransduction concepts
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to engage in academic discussions of classic and current research articles
Ability to bridge the knowledge gap between biological and physical sciences
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to analyze physical science concepts
Ability to understand and analyze biological phenomena
Ability to utilize models to predict cell mechanical behavior

courseTitle: Independent Study in Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering
courseDescription: Individual analytical, computational and/or experimental study in an area selected by the student.  Supervised and approved by the advisor.

Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in mechanical and aerospace engineering

Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analytical skills for investigating hardening mechanisms
Problem-solving skills in nanoscale material properties

courseDescription: Divided into areas of fatigue and fracture; stress-controlled and strain-controlled fatigue; effect of mean stresses, notches, etc.; multiaxial stresses; variable amplitude loading; ductile and brittle fracture; linear elastic fracture mechanics; crack-tip plasticity; fracture testing; applications to fatigue life estimation.  Requires permission of the instructor.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of stress-controlled and strain-controlled fatigue
Understanding of the effect of mean stresses and notches
Understanding of ductile and brittle fracture
Proficiency in linear elastic fracture mechanics
Ability to apply knowledge to fatigue life estimation
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to seek and obtain instructor's permission
Ability to explain complex concepts related to fatigue and fracture
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the effects of variable amplitude loading
Problem-solving in the context of linear elastic fracture mechanics
Analyzing the effects of mean stresses and notches

courseDescription: An examination of the macroscopic behavior of materials with respect to elasticity, plasticity, and viscoelasticity; yield criteria; fracture; influence of high and low temperatures; and corrosion and radiation.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of elasticity, plasticity, and viscoelasticity
Understanding of material behavior at high and low temperatures
Knowledge of corrosion and radiation effects on materials
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in material deformation and failure
Analyzing influence of temperature on materials
Identifying and analyzing corrosion and radiation effects

courseDescription: This course will examine reinforcements, matrices, particulate-composites, short-fiber and continuous-fiber reinforced composites. Directionally solidified composites will also be studied, including the prediction of elastic failure properties. Other topics to be covered include design considerations and experimental work.
Technical and Digital Skills: Proficiency in short-fiber and continuous-fiber reinforced composites
Ability to predict elastic failure properties
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Designing and managing composite materials projects

courseDescription: An applied course in response surface methodology with aerospace applications.  Empirical model building, method of least squares, second order models, model adequacy checking, canonical analysis.  Method of steepest ascent, multiple response optimization.  Rotatable, cuboidal and small run designs.  Design optimality and efficiency metrics, robust design, restrictions on randomization.  Laboratory exercises include RSM applied to wind tunnel testing and optimization.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of rotatable, cuboidal and small run designs
RSM application to wind tunnel testing and optimization

courseDescription: Formulation and solution algorithms for Linear Programming (LP) problems.  Unconstrained and constrained nonlinear programming (NLP) problems.  Optimum solution for practical engineering systems.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of unconstrained and constrained nonlinear programming (NLP) problems
Optimum solution modelling for practical engineering systems
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving for LP and NLP problems
Application of optimization techniques to solve engineering problems

courseDescription: Concepts, principles and procedures related to analysis of stresses and strains in machine components.  Consideration of function of parts along with factors such as forces, life required, maximum cost, weight and space restrictions, number of parts to be produced, material selection, kinematics,environmental restrictions.  Finite element analysis to illustrate different aspects of stress analysis.  Requires permission of the instructor.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of forces, life required, maximum cost, weight and space restrictions, number of parts to be produced

courseDescription: This course will introduce the engineering of industrial robots used for manufacturing automation. Topics to be covered include spatial descriptions and transformations of manipulators, manipulator kinematics and inverse kinematics; manipulator velocities; static forces; and dynamics and trajectory generation. Other topics to be covered include design and on-line computer control of the manipulator.
Technical and Digital Skills: Spatial descriptions and transformations of manipulators
Understanding of dynamics and trajectory generation
Design and on-line computer control of the manipulator
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in manipulator velocities and static forces

courseDescription: Treatment of the next generation of manufacturing technology.  Topics include additive manufacturing; rapid prototyping; electronic manufacturing; micro and nanofabrication; process simulation; product life cycle management; and sustainable design and manufacturing.

courseTitle: Computational Intelligence for Engineering Design Optimization Problems
courseDescription: The concepts and algorithms of computational intelligence and their application to engineering design are discussed, including artificial neural networks, evolutionary optimization, and swarm intelligence. Both single and multi-objective optimization problems with continuous and/or discrete variables are also discussed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Managing single and multi-objective optimization problems
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing and solving complex engineering design problems
Application of computational algorithms to solve optimization problems

courseDescription: An introduction to managing uncertainties and risk in strength design of mechanical components, including the study of theoretical background, computational implementation, and applications of reliability-based methods for engineering analysis and design.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of reliability-based methods for engineering analysis and design
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Risk management in mechanical component design

courseDescription: A broad introduction to the field of cellular biomechanics. Topics include overview of cell architecture, cytoskeleton, adhesion and molecular motors, biomolecular/biopolymer dynamics and mechanics, techniques to measure cell mechanical properties, techniques to mechanically stimulate cells, models of cell mechanical behavior, mechanobiology and mechanotransduction. Will include discussion of classic and current research articles.   Course content will aim to cater to students with diverse backgrounds – students with biological science background will be exposed to physical science concepts and analysis; students with engineering/physical science background will be exposed to biological phenomena and concepts.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of cytoskeleton, adhesion and molecular motors
Understanding of biomolecular/biopolymer dynamics and mechanics
Ability to measure cell mechanical properties
Understanding of models of cell mechanical behavior
Ability to analyze physical science concepts
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Participating in discussions on classic and current research articles
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying physical science concepts to biological phenomena

courseTitle: Independent Study in Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering
courseDescription: Individual analytical, computational and/or experimental study in an area selected by the student.  Supervised and approved by the advisor.

courseTitle: PhD Dissertation Research in Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering
courseDescription: Based on the Ph.D candidate's dissertation research in mechanical and aerospace engineering topics under the direction of the candidate's advisor.
Technical and Digital Skills: Advanced knowledge in mechanical and aerospace engineering
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in mechanical and aerospace engineering

courseDescription: This course is a pass/fail course for master's students in their final semester. It may be taken to fulfill the registration requirement necessary for graduation.  All master's students are required to be registered for at least one graduate credit hour in the semester of their graduation.
